Award.AwardTitle: DMREF: Emergent Functionalities at the Epitaxial Interfaces of Correlated and Spin-Orbit Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
****Technical Abstract****
This collaborative project will combine analytic and predictive computational theory with experimental molecular beam epitaxy (MBE) growth and characterization to investigate the physical phenomena of well-characterized epitaxial materials with dimensions on the order of one to a few unit cells. These materials are expected to have enhanced functionalities such as superconductivity emerging from the interplay of strain, proximity to the substrate, and correlations and spin-orbit interactions. Through the use of different substrates, the doping, spin-orbit strength, correlations, and magnetic coupling can be varied, thus mapping out large areas of phase space appropriate to different models of superconductivity. The material systems to be studied include the three-dimensional topological insulators (TI) and Fe-based superconducting thin films grown by MBE on various substrates. The research will address issues related to 1) the proximity-induced superconductivity in 3D TIs; 2) the effect of interfacial bonding on superconducting properties of ultrathin FeSeTe films; 3) the polarization doping of Fe-based superconductors at interfaces; and 4) the strain-induced normal to topological insulator transitions. In situ scanning tunneling microscopy and spectroscopy will be used to study the electronic and superconducting properties, coupled with ex situ scanning transmission electron microscopy and transport measurements. Density functional theory calculations will be used to determine the normal state properties of the bulk and surface materials and, with the ability to vary parameters such as spin-orbit coupling strengths, these calculations will constrain and provide realistic input to different models of superconductivity. Together, the various calculations will help optimize the experiments in an iterative manner, as well as providing a deeper understanding of the physics.

****Non-Technical Abstract****
Advances in predictive computational electronic structure theory, models of correlated systems, and the ability to engineer the structure of materials at the atomic scale provide the opportunity of synthesizing materials with specific properties. In this project, experiment and theory will work closely and iteratively to produce "designer materials" that can further our understanding of the fundamental materials physics as well as being of potential technological use. Specifically, well-characterized epitaxial films of topological insulators and iron-based superconductors a few atomic layers thick will be grown on different substrates. At these spatial dimensions, properties can vary significantly compared to the bulk, possibly generating novel physics and emergent functionalities through the interplay of strain, proximity to the substrate, correlations, and spin-orbit interactions. Participating graduate and undergraduate students benefit from a highly collaborative and multidisciplinary research training.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The fundamental physical phenomena of well-characterized thin layers of epitaxial materials were investigated through a collaborative and integrated program combining analytic and predictive computational theory with experimental growth and atomic-scale characterization, that made use of the complementary expertise of the principal investigators. A major scientific focus was on the properties of ultrathin (single atomic layer) films of iron-based superconductors and of other exotic materials (e.g., half-Heuslers), with the goal of understanding how the interplay of strain, interactions with substrates, correlations, magnetism, and spin-orbit coupling may lead to enhanced functionalities, including superconductivity. During the course of this project, we have developed and extended theories of superconductivity, demonstrated the importance of magnetic order (and fluctuations) and spin-orbit effects on the underlying electronic structure, and showed how the functionalities and properties may be tailored at the nanoscale by proximity to other materials and/or by modifying the atomic structure. For example, we demonstrated not only that one-dimensional superconductivity along the edges of nanoribbons can exist, but also that it can be controlled by varying the chemical composition. The Materials Genome Initiative (MGI) approach of iterative feedback among the various experimental and theoretical components was essential to carrying out the research: the theoretical calculations provided guidance for the experimental studies, and the experimental results in turn suggested possible modifications of the theories and new avenues of investigation.
The scientific results of this project expand the knowledge base in the rapidly expanding areas of thin-film superconductivity and topological materials, two areas of research that potentially may lead to new nanodevices with tailored properties. In addition, the project provided research opportunities and mentoring for undergraduate and graduate students, who received training in both experimental materials science and advanced condensed matter theory. This blurring of the traditional divisions between theory and experiment represents a paradigm shift in the education of the next generation of researchers and should benefit them in their future careers.  Besides publications, the results of the research – and the MGI philosophy underlying it – have been conveyed to the wider community through the participation as invited speakers at a number of international workshops, and through outreach and recruitment activities at local schools.
